This trip to Greece, which seemed like a pipe dream but weeks ago, is less than a week away - and I'm nervous as all get out! I have the nagging feeling that I have yet to sort everything out for the trip -- and I haven't, and my first task is to sort out a checklist of the details that need to be actioned/purchased/obtained for this trip. There's still packing to be done too... Argh! I think I will definitely take the Friday off work to make sure I have everything sorted out for this trip. But this is a much-needed trip as, lately, I've felt as if things are feeling too much of a rigmarole - so this change will help me get my mind off work and the usual day-to-day stuff. And when I'm back, I shall be in a better frame of mind for work and for handling.., the garden! :-)

This has been a pretty full-on weekend though. So much for winding down before my trip. Spent most of yesterday out with Guy Mac - we went to GG's exhibition at UWA, then Mac wanted to get a red filter so we wandered around the camera stores in Perth a bit, had lunch, went to Hillarys in the afternoon for an evening 'shoot. I picked up my entries for the City fo Belmont Art Awards - where Veronica recognised me again (what wonderful people they have staffing that exhibition). This morning, I covered the last winter swim for the Trigg Blue Hole Club; there was an after-swim presentation and Brian Carthew gave a speech, part of which acknowledged me as the "accidental photographer". Nice! They even set the photos taken on a slideshow streamed through the TV sets in the surf club common room.

My entry in the City of Melville Art Awards did not sell. I've put the photo up at the APs place - when looking at it again, I think that the colours are a little muddy. I must confess that I entertained some hope that the photograph might have sold. I guess we all do.

This week will be focused on getting the smaller, more detailed tasks completed in preparation for the trip. Fun!

Grinners
Originally uploaded by sengster.
I would never had expected it in a month of Sundays -- primarily because it caused me such angst - but Nath and I took out both 'Highly Commended' prizes in the Photography section of the City of Belmont Art Awards.

They announced the 'Highly Commended' prizes first and Nath's name was first announced. I was so stoked for him and shook his hand as he went up to receive his prize. As I was just clapping, I heard them mention my name and the title of the photograph but it took a second or two for it to register. You know when they say "you can't believe your ears" - I now understand what that means!

Wagon!

I'm still buzzing from this experience!!

It appears that I have had the blogger's block. Or rather, I've had a very busy week and weekend. This weekend has seen me away from home for more than 24 hours. Seriously! I left home yesterday at about 9am to drop off my entry for the Melvile City Art Awards... and I've only returned home today circa 1.30pm. But this should be the last of the crazy weekends and I should settle back into some semblance of normalcy this week. I hope.

What's happened in the last week. The most upsetting thing that has occured is that Mac lost his job after only 1 week in the new position. It was very sudden and abrupt, and a clear indication of what a bastard employer Vivid-Design is, especially given how taken he was with the job. He called me on Monday after work, which I first thought was just a social, catch-up call, until I heard his voice quavering on the other end of the phone. He was very upset, so I drove up to his place and stayed with him until Kt came back from work. On Wednesday, I spent the day with Mac helping him finish a freelance project so that he could get paid for it - and hence have some income to cover the next few weeks. I've asked him to consider free-lancing for the time being, until he builds up enough experience and familiarity with the application and processes that can make him more efficient as a designer/developer. We finished the site on Wednesday (I took the day off work to help him out), and we talked about a road map forward to cover the next month or so. I think it should be ok. There is quite a bit of potential in the work that he has lined up as a free lancer and we talked about ways of marketing himself to get continued work from his existing clients.

Also dropped off my entries to the Belmont City Art awards on Thursday night - at Belmont Shopping Centre. That was a weird place - never have I felt so much a fish out of water. There's a certain element in Belmont that hinted at violence -- not sure if it's something I imagined, but I didn't feel very comfortable walking around the mall. I also got my framed print back - what a beauty it is and I really hope it sells at the Melville Art Awards Exhibition. I've also decided to put in for the Red Lens competition - and sent three images for printing at Fitzgerald's on Saturday.

Spent most of Saturday hanging with Mac and Nath - going to the PCP and Breadbox to check out the photography exhibitions there, and felt quite heartened by what we saw. Had dinner at S and J's last night - it was good fun; Oz and T were invited too, and it all started to get a bit overwhelming - Oz has this very overpowering way of communication that tends to make me want to switch off. It's difficult to put my finger on it, but I think it's a combination of the way he takes over a conversation, or makes points or statements that sound like demands. I ended up sleeping over in the spare room at S and J's as I was dog-tired, and had a fitful night's sleep.

Today was pretty much spent covering the Blue Holes Club swim at Trigg Beach, and then doing a 'shoot there with S and J, followed by Lunch at the Trigg Island Cafe on the beach front. Largest plate of grilled calamari I have ever had. Then it was home to do a few paltry chores - the clothes are washed; the dishes aren't; I still need to clear the mess from the dining table from when I prepared the final bits for the Under H20 exhibition at the LRC.

Speaking of which, the Under H20 portraits are up and despite my initial reservations about their going up in the noticeboard area, I think they work well. I believe a few PIPpers will drop in to have a look. I know that Oz and T already have.

That pretty much brings us to the present. Tomorrow evening's the opening ceremony/presentation of the Belmont City Art Awards at Belmont SC. Then I'll have to get the prints for Red Lens posted to Charles Sturt University... then it's pretty much over and I can focus on getting organised for Greece. Sometimes, it feels like I'm on the last leg of my journey to chuck the Ring of Power into Mt Doom... and that I will soon emerge uttering, like Frodo: "It's gone. It's done."

Phew.

Census night tonight - it made for quite an interesting exercise. I'd forgotten that we had completed a census back in 2001 - also with the option of having the details released in 99 years. Interesting development - I have now listed myself as 'Buddhist' in this census.

Well, Guy's having fun in his new job - and I'm glad for him. I received the following SMS from him at about 10.30 am yesterday:

"I cannot express my happiness at the moment. It's like I'm in a dream job."

Good for you, Mr. Mac.

I prepared a print for the Melville Art comp - brought it on CD to Fitzgerald's today to be printed with Ultrachrome. Fitzgerald's has come onboard as a major sponsor for our exhibition (www.frompixeltoprint.com) with a 50% discount on all printing. Yay.

I feel a lot better since Sunday when I was in a foul, foul mood and feeling very frustrated because none of the mounting of the prints for the LRC exhibition was going well. Speaking of which, I still need to speak with Bernadette at the centre to set up an area for the exhibition. Not sure if I want to have a low-key launch -- feels a bit tacky to do it.  I'll still need to think about contacting he community papers about it... running a bit short on time. :-)

I booked my 3 nights accommodation in Athens at the Student and Travellers' Inn, within the Plaka. It's a dorm but I figure it should be ok as I'll be sleeping mostly on the first night, and then will be out and about on the next couple of days.

That's about it for now.

It's been quiet of late in this blog. I've been busy.

A quick catch-up.

1. Guy and I went to the Liquid Images exhibition at Pt Heathcote on Saturday. It was, again, heartening to realise that the work we see hanging on the walls was easily within our achievement.

2. The guys and I are planning a photography exhibition. Thus far, it seems that I'm doing most of the driving (a trifle disappointing as I thought there would be more enthusiasm from them) but it's still early days and I know that ppl like Shem and Nath are busy at the moment. We're still trying to formalise  a concept plan for the exhibition.

3. Went to Shem and Jazz's for dinner last night -- Shem made great roast lamb rubs on the rack, with roast vegs that were absolutely "to die for".

4. I printed out 8x12s of three photographs for entry in the Royal Show photography competition. Spent today mounting them... I think they look ok, but we'll see how they go. I'll have to post them tomorrow for them to make it in by Wednesday (procrastinating, the thief of time!).

I'll write more later. There's an interesting report on 60 Minutes about the guy who traded his way from a red paper clip to a house.

Israel has gone mad. It is attacking Lebanon - Beirut to be exact; attacking another sovereign nation and ignoring the urging of the UN and other nations to desist. Typically, Australia, the UK and the US are very quiet about the affair - our tacit support of Israel's unconscionable actions is sickening. Even the news feeds on TV downplay this gross incursion of diplomacy and human rights. Israel claims that it has no choice but to attack Hisbollah installations, as two of its soldiers have been captured by Hisbollah, but the reality of it is that Israel has targetted civilian communities (how else can you explain the gross number of civilian casualties?). Worse of all, front page news on The West today wasn't about this act of gross and outright terrorism by Israel, nor of the human tragedy that it has caused. No: instead, we are treated to a front page article on how this conflict will raise the price of fuel to $1.70 a litre in a few weeks. Our national apathy is gut churningly awful. It makes me want to run out and slap some sense into people: stop thinking about yourself and the preservation of your comfortable lifestyle for once, for fuck's sakes!

On another note, I went to the Murmurs photography exhibition at the Freo Arts Centre with Guy Mac, Nath and Suz. There was a real variety of photographs of Paris taken by Australian photographers; after this, we hung around Freo - went for gelati, then a beer at Rosie's. All in all, an enjoyable day out with the trio. I had done a photo shoot at Burswood Park in the morning with Guy, which was ok (not the best location as there was somewhat of a sameness in the landscape). It looks like Nathan and I will be photographing Rob and Sarah's (Guy's sister and brother in law to be) wedding in November. Nathan swore that he wouldn't do it unless I was going to be photographer too - I think having two photogs will make things less stressful.

Oh, and I am definitely Greece-bound: have booked my flight to Athens - departing on 9th Sept, arriving 10th Sept in Athens. About 3 days in Athens, then flying to Iraklio (Heraklion) in Crete. Thus far, my plans are: Perth - Athens - Crete - Amoragos - Santorini - Athens - Perth, all in 3 weeks.

It started raining last night.

I'd left the clothes on the line - overnight.

Never mind. Hopefully, it'll fine up again today and the clothes will get an opportunity to dry.

Lately, I've been thinking about what's important to me -- those things that I most value and without which I would be very lost. And I realised that when it comes down to the crunch, things like photography don't matter at all. I could happily go on without it. My feeling restless about my 'art', my feeling a bit flat and uncreative -- in the long run, these measure up to nil as far as importance goes.

I caught up with Andy-wan on Friday night and enjoyed listening to him telling me about his experiences in the US during his 3 weeks holiday there. In that, I realised that what I would like to do is to gradually get to know a new place by spending about a week there - as I had sort of done with Naxos back in '02. I think I will buy a Lonely Planet Guide to Greece to start me on my planning my trip there.

Ok, that's it. I'm going to take a small break from photography. I just can't get excited about it at the moment.

Having said that, the PIP meet at Little Creatures yesterday was fantastic. 20 people. Lots of socialising. Loved almost every moment of it. I felt completely stimulated by the interaction. Now, I know I'm generally a quiet person and "me time" is important, but, wow, it was fantastic.

A funny day at work. Well, not funny, really. More run of the mill. For some odd reason, the phones kept ringing at lunchtime with interests and prospects. Hm... 

GuyMac went for his Vivid Design interview today. I chatted to him this evening and he said it went ok. Fingers crossed, it will work out.

I like writing these short sentences.

Tomorrow, I'm photographing the lawyers and their team at KSR. Should be fun. Wish I could be more enthused about it, but the pressure to perform is a tad scary. Well, we'll see how it goes.

Oh yeah, I am backing up my computer. Who would've thought it would take so long. I may have to leave the PC on overnight until the backup is complete. Geeze.

I've been thinking a bit more about my issue now. Not as much. I have no effing idea how to resolve it. I don't think there is a way to solve it. I think it's just a case of not doing anything and seeing what happens, which isn't an easy thing.

Still haven't decided if I should see the allergist though. I called the health insurance fund today to find out if I'd be covered but the strange guy at the other end of the 'phone told me that I would only be covered if I were hospitalised, and that a visit to an allergist should be covered by Medicare. I wonder if Medicare would cover consultations with allergy specialists or if they would deep this as being a flippant thing in comparison to, say, life-threatening injuries. 

I still can't decide if I should go to Greece. I've started thinking that perhaps I should just head down south in September for a couple of weeks - get all the way to Denmark maybe. What do you think? For some odd reason, escaping to another country just doesn't hold the same appeal.

Should I go to Greece?

Call 11602 if you think I should.
Call 11603 if you think I shouldn't.

Ok, outta here.

I'm feeling a bit down because about 1 hour ago, I got a call from GuyMac who told me that he's just lost his job. They decided not to continue with his employment at the end of his 3 month probation. Guy said that he has never failed in anything in the past before and this feels as if he's failed. What do you do? What can you do? I feel a bit helpless at the moment. Don't know why I get affected like that by things that happen to other people.

Not like there's anything I can do to change the situation.

I hope he does well in the interview on Monday.

Why can't my luck rub off on my friends?

Share the luck,

Share the well being.

Winter solstice - the shortest day of the year. Heh heh heh...

I think I'm spending too much time on photography and I need to take a break from it. When it starts feeling as if I'm obsessing, I know it's time to take a break. So - no photos... not until this weekend. And also, no uploads to FlickR. Not until after this weekend.

I want a holiday from myself.

Can I have one?

Ta.

Quick update:

- Feeling much better, thanks for asking.
- I'm making dinner tonight for Tony and family, and Matt and Michelle; Baby G is of course coming but he isn't into solid foods yet. Will be making my first ever version of a claypot. :-)
- Sunset 'shoot at Mettams tomorrow. Huzzah!

I can't believe that I'm still sick. It's been almost a week, given that I've traced the onset of this cold to since last Thursday. Big sigh.

Wasn't firing on all cylinders at work yesterday. In fact, just after lunch, it was a struggle to keep up. I gave up and just did mundane, mindless work. I'll go in today but it my condition doesn't improve, I'm going to take half a days sickie.

I'm not sure what more I can do save capitulate and get the prescribed antibiotics, which even the GP recommended against.

Let me list my ailments:

- lethargy
- slight headache
- cold
- sore throat
- unpleasant expectoration
- drowsiness
- hot/cold flushes
- cold extremities

If this ain't the flu, I don't know what is!!!!!

I had a dream last night. I was somewhere with Dave and Jac and Dave asked Jac to go to the coast to get some ice-cream. I decided to follow her. As we went down the slope that ran by the cliff side to the coast, I noticed that the light that fell on Jac's face turned her eyes a crystalline blue. So, I asked if she would pose for a photo. I took the shot, zooming in to frame her incredibly icy eyes, and noticed that the shutter closed with an odd clunk. When I previewed the image, I noticed that it was actually a wider shot than the closer frame that I had used via the zoom. Later, I wasn't able to take any more photos with the camera and I heard a rattling sound coming from within. I removed the lens, to discover that the mirror had come off. Panicking, I tried to slip it back in, being very careful not to touch the sensor; but the bloody thing began to crumble in my fingers. Before I knew, it the interior of my camera had turned into something of the consistency of wet sand.

By this stage, Jac had hurried off to get the ice-cream leaving me stumbling down the steps to the beach with the broken camera. I knew it was still under warranty and I could send it to be fixed, but the thought of being without my cam for weeks on end was quite distressing. Then, up the steps came two women I knew in the dream (but not in real life) -- I tried explaining my predicament to them, and they were sympathetic. By this stage, I was almost beside myself with distress at the state of my camera.

Then, I woke up and realised, with tremendous relief, that it was only a dream.

I wonder what part of my subconscious was working overtime with this dream. :-o

I'll be taking another sickie today. Feeling very unwell. 2 sickies in a row and after a weekend to boot. How can I live with myself?? :-o

But, the reality is that my nose and throat are clogged up and I feel drowsy most times, so it's definitely the 'flu. On the plus side, I don't have a fever, for which I am most thankful.

I went to get some Codral from the local pharmacy yesterday, and found out that due to recent changes in legislation, all pharmacists are now keeping a register of purchases of medication with pseudo-ephadrine, which meant them committing my contact details and driver's licence number to a database. Then, when I went to the Post Office to send the disposable cam to the next fotomodachi, I discovered that all non-document packages sent overseas needed to have the sender's personal details committed to a database, because of new anti-terrorism legislation. Twice in one day, I've had to provide my contact and personal details for entry into a database. If this isn't cause for concern, I don't know what is. How did the government manage to put through legislation where our information has suddenly become so easily collectible? Whatever happened to right to privacy? No doubt, there are arguments that could be put forward to back up this kind of data collection eg. preventing abuse of over-the-counter medication, but it was certainly a very odd experience to have to render my personal information over to a database twice in one morning! It was enough to get me thinking along slightly paranoid lines.

Also watched 3 eps of Season 2 of BSG yesterday - was good, but I kept drifting to sleep as I had the heater on and was curled up on the couch. Today, I think I will get a couple of new release DVDs and watch them eg. The Constant Gardener which I have been meaning to watch for some time.

On the plus side, my landscape photographs in FlickR seem to be getting some air time - a handful of them have made Explore, and one shot of waves caught in long exposure crashing against rocks seems to have amassed nearly 900 views. It is quite ironic as landscape isn't really my thing as far as photography goes, though I'm starting to really enjoy the dawn and evening jaunts, and getting excited when I realise that I have caught the right moment, be it light or motion.

Ok, enough for today. Back to your scheduled programming.

After the evening shoot at Mettam's Pool with Nath and GuyMac (who is now the proud owner of a Nikon D70s), I went to see baby Ashley Kingston with Dave and Jac. It's amazing to see how comfortable Xtie is with the baby - having had Saf, I think she's more confident and at ease with bringing up baby. It was funny to hear her talk about Anthony's early uneasiness with handling the baby as Ashley is his first. I got to cradle baby Kingston in my arms - he slept for most of it until he woke after making a deposit in his nappy, while still in my arms (!) He's surprisingly heavy for a little feller, and looks remarkably like a cross between Anthony and the Laughing Buddha.

It's also good to see GuyMac so happy with his new D70s. The sunset at Mettam's was breath-taking and the image of Guy perched on the rocks, silhouetted against a fiery red sky will remain in my memory for a long while. Of course, I also have a couple of photographs of that but being there and seeing that magnificent sky blazing in all that colour is really a once-off. Reminds me of that time I was at Naxos, and I walked up to the Portara and sat there looking at the sunset behind the outer islands. No words can describe the elation. I think Guy expressed it best when he raised his arms and whooped out loud.

The kind of sunset that grabs hold of you body and soul.

I have a fair few jobs to do around the house today - clean the bathrooms, vacuum the carpets, tidy things up. I think once I get the place into some kind of order, I will begin feeling a bit more settled after the hectic last couple of weeks.

I also need to reconnect with Matt and Michelle - to see if they are able to come to dinner next Saturday.

Work today wasn't too bad, despite my having a head cold. Admittedly, I was almost nodding off as I drove there - having a head cold makes me drowsy.

At work today, I had a nice Skype chat with my mate, Guy Mac, who said some nice things about me, that made my day. Thanks Mr Mac.

It is so cold tonight. I had the heater on while I caught up with the current episode of Lost - then I decided to come here and go online. And it's so cold. Definitely a night for the electric blanket.

I was going to get some ISO800 film to do underwater portraits tomorrow but would you believe that none of the photo-processing stores in and around Cottesloe's main strip stocked it? So, I will just spend the weekend planning how to approach more formal underwater portraiture.

In the last hour, I have been feeling progressively ill. I'm shivering and no amount of jumpers will stop the chill. My nose is now completely blocked and my eyes feel as if they're about to dribble out of my sockets. My ears are freezing. I have no feeling in my toes. I don't want to go to work, but I have to or I'll feel bad. I don't know why.

It appears that I have caught a mild cold. Well, that's a self-diagnosis anyway: my nose is blocked, throat is sore and I feel as though there is a mild build up of pressure in my head.

The people I hang out with in the PIP FlickR group are an interesting bunch. There is a very strong distinction in the culture within the group, between the urbane urbanites - those in more comfortable circumstances financially and career-wise, who typify all that is chic about inner-city living - and the country boys from Albany, who are in transition, lifestyle and career-wise, and who must deal with the more pressing urgencies of work, partners, budgets and so on. Personally, I prefer hanging out with the latter, perhaps because they are quieter and their outlook in life more closely reflects mine. What impresses me also is their terrific commitment to their partners; they speak of their partners with a great deal of openess, respect and affection. They are closer to my age (in their early 30s) and are probably going through the same life decisions that I went through at that age too. The urbanites are a more mixedgroup age-wise (at 35, I'm the eldest; the younger members are around 21-24), and I think this is what fuels the hedonism that permeates the group culture. There are also a couple of strong personalities in this group which, coupled with solid finances and the greater feeling of freedom and autonomy that comes with it, certainly gives this group a bit more buzz that can be both attractive and exhausting.

I started taking underwater portraits on Wednesday, after receiving my Vivitar Cruise Cam (underwater point and shoot camera) on Tuesday. It was a real challenge to frame the shots underwater, and about 50% of the shots went to waste. I was also a little disappointed in the lack of clarity, though this may be due to my being unused to having to position myself at least 1.5 metres away from the subject. Still, it occassioned much hilarity amongst the early morning swimmers, particularly Liz and the 2 Pams, though they were sporting enough to pose for a few shots. Terry also posed for a couple of shots, and I wanted to get one of Italia, but she must have drifted out partly out of frame. I'm going to think more carefully about how I should take photographs under water and will try and organise a more 'formal' series of underwater portraits next week. I'm going to use Kodak 800 film though as I suspect that the lack of clarity from the first 'shoot was due to film slowness (Kodak 400).

This weekend promises to be interesting and enjoyable - what with Xtie, Anthony, Safe and Ashley down from Goomaling (I'll be visiting tomorrow night), and 2 'shoots - one at sunset at Mettam's Pool, the other a late afternoon shoot at Fremantle Harbour. I'll have to fit in cleaning the house in between. And also possible catching up with Matt and Michelle - at the very least, a phone call to see if they are able to come over for a BBQ on Saturday next week.

Long weekend... wherefore art thou long weekend?

How can three days fly by so quickly and unceremoniously?

Still, it was a chock full weekend - I took time to enjoy 'me time' now that AM and family have flown back to Malaysia. I was supposed to have a bbq on Saturday night for Tony and family, but Tony called on Friday to say that Jen had been admitted for surgery due to some damage to her shoulder and tendons from the accident. They've only just discovered the damage as her specialist called for an MRI scan during her last check up. She's back home now but her right arm is in a sling.

Went on a dawn shoot with GuyMac on Sunday morning - we decided to head to Mettam's Pool in North Perth. It was cold, but I enjoyed being outdoors in the early hours this time, though I must have still been half-asleep as I had a couple of near misses while driving there. I had a couple of good shots, but still think that the photographs look a bit flat. Poor Guy must think that I'm a bad driver! Guy wore glasses on Sunday - I didn't even know that he usually wore contacts; turned out that he was born with cataracts and had his lens removed when he was 11, so has always worn very powerful glasses and/or contacts since.

Cocktail at the Bisluk's on Sunday night. Had a Singapore Sling, which was very nice (and sweet), followed by margheritas courtesy of Scroop, and a few other concoctions, one of which include absinthe and a chocolate block (!), and another which Brendan made. I think I got quite merry that night. A couple of Shem's workmates from WestNet came but for some reason I didn't talk much with them - now feel a bit bad about it as I usually make a point to speak with people. Perhaps I was just feeling a bit flat that evening until the alcohol kicked in, and by then, I was pretty much yammering away with Brendan and Dannielle.

I think I'm getting a bit addicted to the Perth FlickR socials. :-)

Today, Tony came with the trailer and we went to pick up the clothes rack from Jac and Dave's. It's now in the guest room and looks mighty fine - it's a good contraption, as it has a rail for you to hang your clothes as well as racks for t-shirts, towels etc. Tony helped me clear the patio area of the stuff we moved there to clear the garage for Gil's digging machine (did I mention I had about $1500 worth of drainage work done to the backyard???? Sigh...), then we picked the oranges from the tree - about 3 bags full. Who'd have thought one little tree could yield so many oranges?

I also caught up with eps of <i>Lost</i> from the last couple of weeks - couldn't watch them due to the rellies visiting and occupying most of my time.

And, as I fear that this entry is becoming very prosaic, I thought I'd finish with the following: Secrets are very difficult to keep.

Urgh. 2 kilos gained in less than a week. :-( A consequence of too much eating out and a family dinner almost every night since AM, UD and E arrived in Perth. After tomorrow, it'll have to be a lean and mean diet again.

In other news:
- My mate, Guy Mac, cut his hand badly while cutting bones up for his dogs. Sliced into his knuckles and cut into his tendons. He said that his tendons were visible. Yuck. He spent 6 hours in emergency at Charlie Gairdner Hospital waiting for it to be seen to.
- I took UD and E to Rottnest yesterday. All in all, we rode for about 10 kilometres. Even though we were only 4 hours on the island, I was so tired at the end of it. And it was very cold. I had three layers on and was still shivering. E and UD seemed unaffected by the cold.
- Interestingly, AM is very protective of UD and E. I understand about E as he is their only child and I think she is protective of UD since his health scare a couple of years back.
- Other places I took the visiting rellies: Caversham Wildlife Park, Whiteman Park and Mundaring Weir.
- I won the bid on the Vivitar Cruise underwater camera, so I'll have to start kicking this underwater project into gear soon.
- 2 more days until the long weekend.
- Cocktails at Shem and Jazz's this weekend.
- Having the Sinagras over for a BBQ - will have to make this Saturday as the cocktail has been shifted to Sunday.

That's about it for now. Ciao!
